sense.def: a small animal with fur and long ears that lives in a hole in the ground

sense.def: If the police raid a place, they suddenly visit it in order to find someone or something or to stop an illegal activity.
dictionaryExamples: The FBI said it had no plans to raid the suspect’s farm.

Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

Learner example: My friend's farm is near to the lovely mountain range, and there are beautiful countryside views as well. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

blocks.phrase: range from sth to sth/between sth and sth

                   has fallen.

                   are very low.

a rational argument/debate/explanation

sense.def: in the natural state

raw materials

dictionaryExamples: I like to keep a notebook and pencil within reach.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can you imagine anything more beautiful than [a] mother reading a bedtime story to her little baby? First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: If you read between the lines, you understand what something really means when it hasn't been directly said or written.
dictionaryExamples: Reading between the lines, it was obvious that something was wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All songs send positive thoughts and messages to listeners, although sometimes you really have to read between the lines to understand this profound message. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: read out sth or read sth out

sense.def: to read something and say the words aloud so that other people can hear
dictionaryExamples: He read out the names of all the winners.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Michael sat in his fav[or]ite chair while his wife read out what had happened. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

blocks.phrasalVerb: read over/through sth or read sth over/through

sense.def: to read something from the beginning to the end, especially to find mistakes
dictionaryExamples: I read over my essay to check for errors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought my eyes were deceiving me [so] I read the letter over again. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who reads
dictionaryExamples: He's a great reader.
Many readers of our magazine have contacted us about the last issue on climate change.
He's a very slow/fast reader.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a club of readers. Our motto is "READ AND YOU WILL FEEL FINE!" Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a book containing a simple story for people who are learning to read or learning a language
dictionaryExamples: There are readers at five different levels, from beginner to upper intermediate.

sense.def: the number and type of people who read a particular newspaper, magazine, etc
dictionaryExamples: These magazines have a very young readership.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first one is an issue that has become one of the main subjects of the last ten years and affects the whole world, [so] it will interest your readership. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: quickly and easily
dictionaryExamples: Information is readily available on the Internet.

sense.def: willingly and without stopping to think
dictionaryExamples: He readily admits to having problems himself.
He readily agreed to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Drinking alcohol won't do you any good. There are a lot of friends who [would] readily help you if you decided to give it up. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when someone is willing to do something
dictionaryExamples: They expressed a readiness to accept our demands.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually, the clients appreciate his readiness to use their language and this has often been a significant factor in closing a deal. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when someone is prepared for something
dictionaryExamples: It was time to repair their shelters in readiness for the winter.

sense.def: the activity or skill of getting information from books, newspapers, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I did a lot of reading while I was on vacation.
Both children find writing difficult but their reading is fine.
The diaries make good bedtime reading.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also we do some practice task[s] [on] writing, reading, speaking and spelling. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: to move something slightly or make a small change to something
dictionaryExamples: He readjusted his tie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because the air conditioning was not working properly or because your unfriendly coach driver refused to readjust it, I got [a]cold [from] that day. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to change in order to deal with a new situation, such as a new job or home
dictionaryExamples: The children will have to readjust to a new school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the last couple of days she had gradually readjusted to her normal mode of life, no longer suddenly finding herself attuned to Morgan's odd modality of perceptions and unable to interface properly with her surroundings. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: prepared for doing something
dictionaryExamples: Give me a call when you're ready.
Are you ready to go yet?
We're going at eight, so you've got an hour to get ready.
When will the book be ready for publication?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Are you ready for some painting? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: prepared and available to be eaten, drunk, used, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Is dinner ready?
The kids are ready for bed.
We're moving to new offices, but they won't be ready till next month.
I'll have dinner ready when you get back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The meal will be ready at 6 o'clock. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech

sense.def: existing in fact and not imagined
dictionaryExamples: He's not real you know, he's just a character in a book.
The two principal actors are brothers  in real life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have recently s[een] a program called "Real life". The program is very good because you can see [what] the real world [is like]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not artificial or false
dictionaryExamples: real leather
Paul saw the Beatles at Shea Stadium in 1966 - that ticket is the real thing!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They brought a car for me but not [a] real [one]. Key English Test; A2; Lithuanian

sense.def: true and not pretended
dictionaryExamples: What's the real reason she didn't come?
Is that your real name?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is the real reason why I'm going to stay in England longer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: being the most important or the main thing
dictionaryExamples: The real problem, of course, is money.
The real difficulty was the language, because my children don't speak English.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays people work most of the time with their computers, [and] the internet give[s] them the op[p]ortunity to download whatever they want, even books, but the real problem is that they do not have the time to read them. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to emphasize a noun
dictionaryExamples: She was a real help.
It's a real pain he's not available tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the advertisement it says "your perfect evening out", but it was a real disappointment. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: taken seriously, not pretended
dictionaryExamples: I thought it was just a practice, but apparently it was for real.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought it was a joke but when I saw the signature I knew it was for real. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: showing things and people as they really are, or making them seem to be real
dictionaryExamples: The creatures were all computer-generated but so realistic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I chose this film because I think it is very realistic. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: accepting the true facts of a situation and not basing decisions on things that will not happen
dictionaryExamples: Let's be realistic - we're not going to finish this by Friday.
We have to be realistic about how much we can afford to pay.
It isn't realistic  to expect people to work for so little money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear friends, I think that your ideas are very nice, but we have to be realistic. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: in a way that shows things and people as they really are, or that makes them seem real
dictionaryExamples: The characters are portrayed very realistically.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was realistically captured in the TV reports you have seen. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: in a way that shows that you accept the true facts of a situation
dictionaryExamples: Realistically, we cannot expect to have finished by the weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Realistically, separate schools will probably be with us for a long time to come, but it will remain the least used form of the two. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: the way things or situations really are and not the way you would like them to be
dictionaryExamples: Listening to music is my escape from reality.
Sooner or later you have to face up to reality.
He may seem charming but in reality he's actually an unpleasant person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, your report talks about an audience of less than 2,000 although we were in reality more than 5,000. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the truth about an unpleasant situation
dictionaryExamples: the harsh realities of life
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides we all know the realities of the modern world. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to start to happen or exist
dictionaryExamples: New jobs could become a reality by next month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have made my dream become a reality. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you notice or understand something that you did not notice or understand before
dictionaryExamples: There is a growing realization that education has benefits at many levels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suppose it is only when one starts to think about it that the realization comes about the fact that fashion is part of our everyday life. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Basque

sense.def: when you achieve something that you wanted
dictionaryExamples: the realization of an ambition
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am certain that the realization of such a project would not only be of benefit to me, but also contribute to an enhanced cultural understanding of both the host country and Switzerland. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to notice or understand something that you did not notice or understand before
dictionaryExamples: I didn't realize how unhappy she was.
I suddenly realized I'd met her before.
They didn't realize the danger they were in.
Do you realize that this is the third time you've forgotten?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was on my way to the airport when I realized I wasn't carr[y]ing my suitcase. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: very or very much
dictionaryExamples: She's really friendly/nice.
I really like/love them.
That's really interesting.
It's a really difficult decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really like my lessons, [the] teacher and my new friends. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to give particular importance to a verb, especially a modal verb
dictionaryExamples: I really have to call Ursula this week.
You really shouldn't  worry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really need to study. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used when you are saying what is the truth of a situation
dictionaryExamples: He isn't really angry - he's just pretending.
You don't really expect them to refuse, do you?
She said she was twenty-eight, but really she's over thirty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first lesson was about the present tense and wasn't really difficult for us. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used for replying that something is not true in a way that is less strong than saying "no"
dictionaryExamples: "So was the food good?" "Not really."
"Did you like him?" "Not really."

sense.def: used to express interest or  surprise
dictionaryExamples: "Apparently she's leaving." "Really? When?"
"She's agreed to try parachute jumping with me." "Really? Do you think she'll do it?"

sense.def: an area of knowledge, interest, experience or activity
dictionaryExamples: successes in the realm of  foreign policy
Unfortunately, this area is not within my realm of experience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Reading literature, in particular, as a pastime is the path which leads you to the magic realm of other worlds shaped by a magnificent combination of words, phrases and sentences composing anew and in a totally different way what you experience in your everyday life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: at the back of something
dictionaryExamples: There's a sticker on the rear door/window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In his rear mirror he saw that all [the] lights on the airfield [were] on again. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the back part of something
dictionaryExamples: First class accommodation is towards the rear of the train.
We walked round to the rear of the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The damage seems to be at the rear of the fridge where the motor is situated. International English Language Testing System; C2; Gujarati

sense.def: If you rear children or young animals, you care for them until they are adults.
dictionaryExamples: In these waters they breed and rear their young.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But still the main role of the wom[a]n is to rear her children and be a good assistant to her husband and take care of her home. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Arabic

sense.def: to change the order or position of things
dictionaryExamples: I've rearranged the furniture in my office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe you could rearrange the café to be more classical. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the facts about why something happens or why someone does something
dictionaryExamples: The reason I'm calling is to ask you a favor.
That was the reason for telling her.
There must be a reason why she’s not here yet.
The long commute we have now is one of the reasons that we want to move to the city.
They moved here for good reason - better schools.
For some reason,  he's decided to quit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the reason why I like [mirrors] is I like to look [at] myself. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: something that makes it right for you to think or do something
dictionaryExamples: I think we have reason to be concerned.
They cancelled their vacation for some reason.
She suddenly left, for no reason.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Animals in zoos are in captivity and not in their natural habitat. They live captured there for no reason, as we could learn about them from books or documentaries [instead]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If it stands to reason that something happens or is true, it is what you would expect.
dictionaryExamples: It stands to reason that a child who is constantly criticized will have little self-confidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So it stands to reason that there is no place for Piggy in Jack's world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: somewhat cheap
dictionaryExamples: reasonable prices
Tomatoes are very reasonable at this time of year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are nature lovers, you should visit some small villages where you can find [a] peaceful atmosphere, delicious, fresh food and everything [at a] reasonable price. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: big enough or large enough in number or amount, although not big or not many
dictionaryExamples: There were a reasonable number of people there.
It's a reasonable salary for that job.
We have a reasonable chance of winning the game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of them have good places for sightseeing and a reasonable [amount of] nightlife. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: good enough but not the best
dictionaryExamples: The service at the hotel is reasonable but don't expect 5-star treatment.
I'd say her work is of a reasonable standard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From my Certificates you can see that I speak English very well and that I have [a] reasonable knowledge [of] Italian and Spanish. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: fair and showing good judgment
dictionaryExamples: It's not reasonable to expect people to work such long hours.
If you tell him what happened, I'm sure he'll understand - he's a reasonable man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, reasonable rules are important for us but be[ing] too strict will bring stress, w[hi]ch causes kids [to] be afraid of many things. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: based on facts that can be explained
dictionaryExamples: There will be a reasonable explanation for all of this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you will be able to offer me [a] reasonable explanation [for] these mistakes and report correct information in your newspaper. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: the process of thinking about something in order to make a decision
dictionaryExamples: I don't understand the reasoning behind this decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to this line of reasoning, its supporters believe that although sports people sacrifice a lot [of] their time, the huge amounts of money that they earn are illogical in comparison with the job they are doing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: something that you say to make someone stop worrying
dictionaryExamples: Despite my reassurances that she was welcome, she wouldn't come.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I very much like being around people and need the reassurance of being well liked. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to say something to stop someone from worrying
dictionaryExamples: He reassured me that I would be paid soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Making my own decisions gives me much stress because I am always so scared of the results and I need to be reassured that I am doing the right thing all the time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: making you feel less worried
dictionaryExamples: a reassuring smile/voice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a reassuring feeling. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: someone who fights against the government in their country, especially a soldier
dictionaryExamples: The rebels took over the capital and set up a new government.
Rebels seized control of the airport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, the police came [o]nto [the train], and killed all [the] rebels. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to refuse to obey rules that you disagree with or do not like
dictionaryExamples: Children often  rebel against eating certain foods - Rory won't eat vegetables.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His brother was never kind with her and she always wanted to rebel. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: when people fight against the government in their country
dictionaryExamples: Government troops defeated an armed rebellion in the south.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rebellion of the students not only led to the freedom of Greece but it also inspired the local people and the people worldwide to fight for their freedom. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: refusing to obey rules because you do not like authority
dictionaryExamples: a rebellious teenager
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "It was impossible for me to become submissive - I must have been rebellious from my very birth", she recalls. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to build something again that has been damaged or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: The villa was completely rebuilt in 1425 after it had been destroyed by fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's [a] XIX century construction, but they rebuilt it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to make a situation succeed again after something caused it to fail
dictionaryExamples: The country was still struggling to rebuild its economy.
They had to rebuild their lives after the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since more and more people in our modern society have been living in a [highly] urbanized environment and they are isolated from the rest of nature, I think it is vital to make every effort to rebuild healthy relationships with nature. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to remember something
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't recall our instructor's name.
Can you recall what happened last night?
I recall that he promised to send the documents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Right now, I can't recall much of that phone call. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a piece of paper that proves that you have received goods or money
dictionaryExamples: Could I have a receipt?
Make sure you get a receipt for everything you buy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately I had kept the receipts and could show them to him. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the act of receiving something
dictionaryExamples: Items must be returned within fourteen days of receipt.

sense.def: to get something that someone has given or sent to you
dictionaryExamples: Occasionally, he still receives letters from fans.
She received a number of awards during her lifetime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also received many other presents. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: to react to a suggestion or piece of work in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: His first book was not well received.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The English lessons in the mornings were well received but I wonder if it is possible to get more variety? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: happening or starting from a short time ago
dictionaryExamples: Is that a recent photo?
A recent study shows that the country-music audience in New York is growing.
In recent years, sales have decreased dramatically.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear John, Thank you for your recent letter. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: not long ago, or at a time that started not long ago
dictionaryExamples: Have you seen any good films recently?
Until very recently he worked as a teacher.
Recently, I've been feeling tired all the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My grandparents, who recently moved to Spain, were sending me a plane ticket so that I could go there for a visit. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a formal party that is given to celebrate a special event or to welcome someone
dictionaryExamples: a wedding reception
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Next month, I have to fly to London to attend a friend's wedding reception. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: someone who works in a hotel or office building, answering the telephone and dealing with guests
dictionaryExamples: a hotel receptionist
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you can't find [the] information, you must ask the receptionist. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: willing to think about and accept new ideas
dictionaryExamples: She's generally very receptive to ideas and suggestions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As we are very receptive to new ideas, this interaction [will] help us improve our city and take a step forward in making it a nicer place to live or visit. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a period when the economy of a country is not successful and conditions for business are bad
dictionaryExamples: The latest report confirms that the economy is in recession.
The country is now in the deepest/worst recession in over 40 years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now in Japan the recession is getting worse and unemployment [is] increasing. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to fill a battery with electricity so that it can work again
dictionaryExamples: You can recharge these batteries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After buying your mobile phone, it is important to know that it can't be used for an unlimited time. It will have to be recharged and, in the end, it will let you down when most needed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to have a period of rest and relaxation so that you feel energetic again
dictionaryExamples: She took a trip to the south of France to recharge her batteries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is [a] very effective way in which we could rejuvenate ourselves and recharge our batteries in order to face the difficulties [o]f the daily routine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a list of foods and a set of instructions telling you how to cook something
dictionaryExamples: Do you know a good recipe for a multigrain bread?
When I make pies, I don’t need to follow a recipe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually I am going to bring with me some delicious recipes that you are going to be surprised [by]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: doing something dangerous and not caring about what might happen
dictionaryExamples: reckless driving
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And, not to mention all the litter they leave behind, they also damage valuable r[o]ck formations or cliff faces through reckless climbing attempts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when you accept that something is true or real
dictionaryExamples: There is a growing recognition of the scale of the problem.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We easily become seduced by the false image of a perfect world of ads that makes us a part of it as long as we purchase more things with no sense of recognition between a real and a false need. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when someone gets praise, respect or thanks for  something good they have done
dictionaryExamples: Ellen gained recognition for her outstanding work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What they are after, is recognition in their work but not so much for the work itself, but [for] what comes after recognition, which is a rise in the salary! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when you know something or someone because you have seen or experienced them before
dictionaryExamples: I waved at her, but she showed no sign of recognition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything had changed out of all recognition and bore no resemblance to the house he had entered a few minutes ago. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to know someone or something because you have seen, heard or experienced them before
dictionaryExamples: I hadn't seen her for 20 years, but I recognized her immediately.
I recognized her from her picture.
I recognized his voice.
Doctors are trained to recognize the symptoms of different diseases.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had recognized Andy's handwriting as soon as I had seen it. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to accept that something is legal, true or important
dictionaryExamples: She recognized that she had been partly to blame.
The international community has refused to recognize  the newly independent nation-state.
Lack of exercise is recognized as contributing to many health problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recognize that, when the weather is bad, you sometimes get wet. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to remember something
dictionaryExamples: I didn't recollect having seen him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am able to recollect only one single family gathering I did not especially take to. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when you remember something
dictionaryExamples: He had no recollection of the incident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have [a] very vague recollection of my childhood but, of course, there are some things that [have] stayed in my memory. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to say that someone or something is good or suitable for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: Can you recommend a good hotel?
Peter had recommended a restaurant to us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recommend the city of Porto Alegre. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to advise someone that something should be done
dictionaryExamples: The committee recommended that we increase our fund-raising efforts.
I recommend writing down these ideas so you don't forget them.
She has been recommended for promotion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recommend that you apply to work [at the festival] and you will have a great time! First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a piece of advice about what to do in a particular situation
dictionaryExamples: The report doesn't make/offer any new recommendations.
It's my recommendation that this factory be closed immediately.
I bought this computer on John's recommendation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope my recommendations are helpful, and I [hope] you  have a great time! First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to make two different ideas, beliefs, or situations agree or able to exist together
dictionaryExamples: It is sometimes difficult to reconcile science and religion.
How can you reconcile your love of animals with your habit of eating them?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When this is the case, the families caring for them are faced with an uphill struggle, as it is difficult to reconcile the need for earning a living with the care of their relatives. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to accept a situation although you do not like it
dictionaryExamples: Eventually he reconciled himself to living without her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't reconcile myself to the thought that my sister had proved to be smarter than me once again. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to think again about a decision or opinion and decide if you want to change it
dictionaryExamples: We've been asked to reconsider the proposal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We invite your newspaper to reconsider its position, hoping that the council will think about our proposals. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to build something again after it has been damaged or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: They reconstructed the palace exactly as it had been.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir, The student committee greatly appreciate your efforts to resolve our current problems, in particular improving and reconstructing our sports centre. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to create a description of a past event using all the information that you have
dictionaryExamples: The police tried to reconstruct the crime using evidence found at the scene.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Through some letters written by Olivia to her sister Marcia, who lived in Paris in 1923, Anne reconstructs the different episodes, letting the reader imagine all the different scenes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: when you build something again after it has been damaged or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: The reconstruction of the city took decades.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The classrooms are in need [of] immediate reconstruction. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when you create a description of a past event using all the information that you have
dictionaryExamples: A reconstruction of the crime was shown on TV.

sense.def: to store sounds or pictures using electronic equipment, a camera, etc., so that you can listen to them or see them again
dictionaryExamples: They've just recorded a new album.
I recorded that program for you.
a recorded message
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best thing about the phone is it has a camera and it can record anything. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to write down information or store it on a computer so that it can be used in the future
dictionaryExamples: He recorded details of their conversation in his diary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another way to [highlight] the importance of books is to consider them as the "depots" of wisdom and knowledge that exist and ha[ve] been recorded since the beginning of History. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a song or music which has been recorded and which is available for the public to buy
dictionaryExamples: I like their new record.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My room is comfortable but a bit untidy around my stereo because in spite of [having] a lot of records and CDs, I don't have any shelf for them so this is why I'm going to buy a new shelf. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: the best, biggest, longest, tallest, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He ran the 100 meters in 9.79 seconds and broke the world record.
He holds the world record for 100 meters.
She set a new record for the high jump.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, at the moment we hear a lot about Laure Manaudou - she has won many gold medals in swimming, and any time she takes part in a competition, she tends to go faster than her previous personal time record or even faster than the world record!! First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: information that is written on paper or stored on computer so that it can be used in the future
dictionaryExamples: medical/dental records
My teacher keeps a record of absences.
This summer has been the hottest on record.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I have to mention that according to the records from [the] box office, they sold over 5,000 tickets for this music festival. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to understand how someone feels
dictionaryExamples: Most teenagers find it hard to relate to their parents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A soap opera should always be dramatic and not produced too "polished" or "clean" because then people would see it more as a movie, and people never relate as much to a character in a movie as they do to a character played by a good, down-to-earth actor who is apparently struggling as much as everybody [else]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: If people are related, they belong to the same family.
dictionaryExamples: Of course Elise and Linda are related to each other – they’re cousins.
We're related by marriage only.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although they're related to each other, they have rather different characters. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: connected
dictionaryExamples: We discussed unemployment and related  issues.
There's been an increase in criminal activity related to drugs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is also related to my research project. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: someone who belongs to the same family as you
dictionaryExamples: On our trip, we visited friends and relations on both sides of the family.

He's Ken Russell, but he's no relation to 
                          the movie director.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I beg[a]n to play against my relations and friends but I soon found that I could [beat] them without any difficulty. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the way in which two people or groups of people feel and behave toward each other
dictionaryExamples: Relations between the parties are  strained and an end to negotiations isn't in sight.
business/economic relations
diplomatic relations
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The second [film] is "Alice" directed by the world's most respected man within the movie bu[si]ness - of course Woody Allen. Again the good old fellow is totally fascinated by people in general, human relations and reactions. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a connection between two or more things
dictionaryExamples: There was little relation between the book and the movie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another drawback is the relation between space and time. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: when compared with something
dictionaryExamples: Salaries are low in relation to the cost of living.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think television has several advantages but also disadvantages in relation to books. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: about or relating to something
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to ask you something in relation to what you said earlier.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In relation to last month's social program, the sightseeing tour of London was d[i]vine, although we didn't get to see the entire city. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the way two people or groups feel about and behave toward each other
dictionaryExamples: He has a very good relationship with his father.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we studied some phrasal verbs and I was supposed to read a text about feelings and relationships. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a romantic friendship
dictionaryExamples: Are you in a relationship at the moment?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me that he hope[s] that someday we could have a boyfriend-girlfriend relationship for real. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the way in which two things are connected
dictionaryExamples: the relationship between sunburn and skin cancer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The relationship between mind and body has been proved by scientists. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a member of your family
dictionaryExamples: All of these people are my relatives.
There was a party for friends and relatives.
All her close/distant relatives came to the wedding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that there'll be a big party with all your relatives and friends. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: being judged or measured in comparison with something else
dictionaryExamples: the relative prosperity of the West
We weighed up the relative advantages of driving there or going by train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In order to [make] myself clear, let me tell you that as an individual I consider myself a dreamer and in the transition from my late teens to my relative maturity I've considered the words of Hesse in his novel "Gertrude": "The difference between our youth and maturity is that in the first stage we are selfish in all our feelings and actions, while in maturity our top priority is everyon[e] else but [ourselves]..." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when compared to something else
dictionaryExamples: The economy has been declining relative to other countries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This seems true at first sight but when one takes into account the different sizes of population, it becomes clear that every country is more or less equally successful relative to its population. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to become happy and comfortable because nothing is worrying you, or to make someone do this
dictionaryExamples: I find it difficult to relax.
After work I relax with a cup of tea and the newspaper.
The wine had relaxed him and he began to talk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want to relax, Buenos Aires is near a lot of beautiful beaches. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If a part of your body relaxes, it becomes less stiff, and if you relax it, you make it become less stiff.
dictionaryExamples: Try these exercises to relax your neck muscles.

sense.def: the feeling of being relaxed
dictionaryExamples: He plays the piano for relaxation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the countryside you can [go] walking and swimming in the blue se[a].  That's very good for relaxation. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: feeling happy and calm because nothing is worrying you
dictionaryExamples: She looked relaxed and happy walking along with her two boys.
He seemed perfectly relaxed and in control of the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It makes me more relaxed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: A relaxed situation or place is comfortable and informal.
dictionaryExamples: There was a very relaxed atmosphere at the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love this place because [it] has a relaxed atmosp[h]ere and all the staff [are] very friendly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: making you feel relaxed
dictionaryExamples: a relaxing bath
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yoga is a very relaxing activity but not boring at all! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to allow a prisoner to be free
dictionaryExamples: Six hostages were released shortly before noon.
He was released from prison last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It all began when I was released from jail, after a two year conviction [for] jewel theft. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a record or film available for people to buy or see
dictionaryExamples: The band's latest album will be released next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has recently released a new CD on which he spent a lot of time and real[l]y made an effort. First Certificate in English; B2; Slovene

sense.def: a musical recording which is made available for the public to buy
dictionaryExamples: Her latest release is a country-western song that she wrote herself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [This department store] provide[s] the latest cds and dvds, so you are always up to date and never miss new releases. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: never stopping or getting any less extreme
dictionaryExamples: relentless criticism
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have come to the end of a millenium of accelerating and relentless destruction of the environment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that never stops or never gets less extreme
dictionaryExamples: They pestered her relentlessly to take them to the seaside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the killing of the two sensible members of the group, namely Piggy and Simon, Ralph is relentlessly pursued by Jack. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the degree to which something is related or useful to what is happening or being talked about
dictionaryExamples: This point has no relevance to the discussion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One may agree with what has been said or not, but nobody can deny the relevance of the issue, as our future society depends on our present educational system. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: related or useful to what is happening or being talked about
dictionaryExamples: relevant information
Education should be relevant to children's needs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had studied psychology but I couldn't find a job relevant to my studies. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: how reliable something is
dictionaryExamples: I can't vouch for the reliability of these figures.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our customers appreciate in particular the reliability of our products and most of them are prepared to pay a premium price for a high-quality product. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: able to be trusted or believed
dictionaryExamples: a  reliable car
reliable information
Gideon is very reliable - if he says he'll do something, he'll do it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a lot of prizes in school, so I consider myself a hardworking and reliable person. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the good feeling that you have when something unpleasant stops or does not happen
dictionaryExamples: It'll be such a relief when these exams are over.
"James can come tonight."  "Well, that's a relief!"
I  felt such a sense of relief when we finished the project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She heard a[n] ambulance siren [in] the distance and with a sigh of relief, she lost consciousness. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when something stops hurting you
dictionaryExamples: I'd been trying to sleep to find relief from the pain.

sense.def: money, food, or clothes that are given to people because they need help
dictionaryExamples: an international relief operation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In our opinion it is not necessary to practise low-flying because you should take into account that we all live in peace time and the money would [be] better spen[t] on health or relief agencies. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to make pain or a bad feeling less severe
dictionaryExamples: Breathing exercises can help to relieve stress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now science gets the blame for being able to do so much, but not enough to relieve the psych[ologic]al pain. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to take something away from someone
dictionaryExamples: Let me relieve you of your luggage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is nothing they can do on the outside now and they are relieved of their responsibilities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: happy that something unpleasant has not happened or has ended
dictionaryExamples: I'm just relieved that she's safe and well.
I heard a noise and was relieved to find that it was only a cat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She actually felt extremely relieved. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the belief in a god or gods, or a particular system of belief in a god or gods
dictionaryExamples: the Christian/Muslim/Buddhist religion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's quite interesting for me, because I like [the] history of religion. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: relating to religion
dictionaryExamples: a religious holiday
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, I think people need religious and spiritual support and [the] family has to be protected and preserved. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: having a strong belief in a religion
dictionaryExamples: He's a very religious man.
They are both deeply religious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are a religious person, you should get married in a church. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to enjoy something
dictionaryExamples: I don't relish the thought of a twelve-hour flight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But as we gradually grow up and turn into adults, the dependence lessens and we relish our freedom. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: enjoyment
dictionaryExamples: He had baked a cake which the children now ate with relish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My expert knowledge of the latter subject was completely ignored, which left me with the former, the most dreaded of all subjects. This was discussed with relish and the operations were described in such vivid detail that I had to excuse myself and leave the room, because I started to feel faint. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a sauce that you put on food to give it more taste
dictionaryExamples: I ate the burger with some relish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are trays of cut lettuce, leaf lettuce, cut tomato, diced tomato, all kinds of relishes, cheese with bacon spread, barbecue, or whatever you like. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to move to another place
dictionaryExamples: The company relocated to Tokyo.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, as you know I was looking for a new job and for that reason I had to relocate to London in November. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: not wanting to do something
dictionaryExamples: Many victims of crime are reluctant to go to the police.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, Spanish husbands are very reluctant to share the housework. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: in a reluctant way
dictionaryExamples: She reluctantly agreed to step down as managing director.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Reluctantly I am forced to mention that my interpreter's fee should be at least doubled. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: continuing to exist when other things or people have gone or been dealt with
dictionaryExamples: Use half the dough and keep the remaining half covered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I decided to do nothing for the remaining week. I stayed at the beach and spent time swimming, reading and relaxing. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: pieces or parts of something that continue to exist when most of it has been used, destroyed, or taken away
dictionaryExamples: The remains of lunch were still on the table.
We visited the remains of a 12th-century castle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Friedrich II finished the town wall around Altenburg.  Its remains are a tourist attraction now. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to say something that shows your opinion or states a fact
dictionaryExamples: He remarked that he'd be home late.
She remarked on how lovely the house  is.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, as Chris remarked, this route may be very difficult. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: something that you say, showing your opinion about something or stating a fact
dictionaryExamples: He made a remark about the new carpet.
Her remarks on the employment question led to a heated discussion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The man was surprised at her remark and double-checked it reluctantly. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: very unusual or noticeable in a way that you admire
dictionaryExamples: He is a truly remarkable man.
He has a remarkable memory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a remarkable piece of literature, which portrays deep feelings of love and hate, depicts strong and unique characters, [and] reveals eternal concerns with good and bad, life and death. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: in a way that makes you feel surprised
dictionaryExamples: She has remarkably good skin for her age.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for your flight attendants, who are always friendly and remarkably helpful, it would be excellent if they were able to speak other languages apart from English. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: something that makes you better when you are ill
dictionaryExamples: a cold remedy
an effective herbal remedy for headaches
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But it is [debatable] [whether] animals are held to widen our human understanding and to create new remedies to cure people from illnesses or if they are [kept] just to amuse people. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something that solves a problem
dictionaryExamples: The remedy for the traffic problem is to encourage people to use public transportation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should give your deputy more work, and have more free time, which I think is the best remedy in you[r] case. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If you remember a fact or something from the past, you keep it in your mind, or bring it back into your mind.
dictionaryExamples: I can't remember his name.
I don't remember signing a contract.
I’ve been a baseball fan for as long as I can remember.
Just as the door closed he remembered that his keys were inside the room.
"Where did you park the car?" "I can't remember."
Williams will be remembered for his generosity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But [do] you remember? I am [a] vegetarian now. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: to not forget to do something
dictionaryExamples: Did you remember to call Linda?
Remember to bring your passport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember to write me a letter. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: to make someone remember something, or remember to do something
dictionaryExamples: Remind me to mail this package.
Could you remind Paul about dinner on Saturday?
I called Gemma and reminded her that the conference was cancelled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing this e-mail to remind you about our meeting on Tuesday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to be similar to, or make you think of, something or someone else
dictionaryExamples: She reminds me of Elaine.
Her laugh reminds me of Cory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's not an expensive scarf, but I like it bec[a]use it reminds me of my sister; she gave me this scarf for my birthday some years ago. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: something that makes you remember something else
dictionaryExamples: If he forgot to pay his rent, his landlady would send him a reminder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Time is precious" is not interpreted as "carpe diem", but rather as a constant reminder of all our duties, that should be done in as little time as possible to prove ourselves effective. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the feeling that you are sorry for something bad that you have done
dictionaryExamples: He has shown no remorse for his actions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first she thought someone wanted her to feel remorse for not being with her husband when he needed her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: far away
dictionaryExamples: It was a remote mountain village that had no electricity.
His voice sounded remote.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She grew up in a remote area in the North East of Thailand. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: a piece of equipment that is used to control something such as a television or toy from a distance
dictionaryExamples: Have you seen the remote control anywhere?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: TV - a powerful force that keeps us glued for endless hours every day, unable to press the "Off" button on the remote control. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to take something away
dictionaryExamples: Club soda will remove that stain.
Please remove your books from the counter.
He was removed from office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to [make] some changes in my room because I feel that I don't have enough space - maybe I will remove my desk, but I'm not sure yet. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to take something off
dictionaryExamples: Liz removed her jacket and hung it on a chair.
Carefully remove the lid, then stir the paint.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After, I was drenched to the skin and I had to remove all my clothes before going [in]to the restaurant, I let you imagine how ashamed I was when I went in[to] the restaurant completely naked! First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to give someone a decision, opinion, help, etc
dictionaryExamples: payment for services rendered
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, the students have only a 5% discount for the services rendered by the arts centre in contrast to the fact that we agreed initially that a 10% discount would be more adequate. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to cause something or someone to be in a particular state or condition
dictionaryExamples: The trees rendered the road as dark as a tunnel.
She was rendered speechless upon hearing the news.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Inadequate medical care coupled with inevitable worsening of constitution, which is a usual concomitant of an elderly age, renders the old exposed to illnesses and injuries which may wreak havoc with their lives. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to arrange to continue an official agreement that was going to end soon
dictionaryExamples: I've decided not to renew my membership of the tennis club this year.
I forgot to renew my season ticket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I had never been abroad before, I hurriedly went to an office where we can apply for a passport or renew it. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: A renewable form of energy can be produced as quickly as it is used.
dictionaryExamples: a renewable energy source such as wind power
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the use of renewable energy sources is always a challenge. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: A renewable official agreement is one that you can arrange to continue when the time limit is reached.
dictionaryExamples: a 6-month renewable contract
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This seemed like a good enough alternative, but last week I was overwhelmed by the proposal from the company I worked for in London, of going back and working for another 6-month renewable contract, on a shift basis. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when you renew an agreement, contract, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Their licence is up for renewal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest we negotiate a new agreement next year, when the current agreement will be due for renewal. International Legal English Certificate; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: the process of repairing and improving something
dictionaryExamples: They have spent millions on the renewal of the rail system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Like the farmer who carefully tends his plot of fertile land, we should make constructive use of our free time, so that we can reap the benefits of spiritual renewal and rejuvenation, and to fully enjoy the fruits of our labour. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to repair and decorate a building that is old and in bad condition
dictionaryExamples: He has a business renovating old buildings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should also renovate the library and extend the opening hours. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the act of repairing and decorating a building that is old and in bad condition
dictionaryExamples: They spent all their savings on the renovation of an old cottage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Principal, In response to your memo, I am writing to provide you with some suggestions concerning the renovation of [the]Sports Centre, on behalf of the member of the student committee. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: famous
dictionaryExamples: The Lake District is renowned for its beauty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Maria Sandoral is a talented young artist who, at the age of 23, has far more background than a lot of artists. [...] She is renowned for her restless attitude, and for her deep interest in the field. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the amount of money that you pay to live in a building that someone else owns
dictionaryExamples: I pay a higher rent than the other tenants because my room is bigger.
Rents here are very high/low.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I have left my wallet in your house. Please look for it and call me because I have to pay the rent tomorrow. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to pay money to live in a building that someone else owns
dictionaryExamples: He'll be renting an apartment until he can find a house to buy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I rent a[n] apartment. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to pay money to use something for a short time
dictionaryExamples: We could rent a car for the weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want, you can rent a car. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to allow someone to pay you money to live in your building
dictionaryExamples: I rented out my house and went travelling for a year.
My Dad has a cabin that he rents to skiers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My uncle is trying to rent his house. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to organize something again in order to improve it
dictionaryExamples: He's completely reorganized his schedule for the week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope that my suggestions will be helpful to you in reorganizing this program. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to fix something that is broken or damaged
dictionaryExamples: They're repairing the holes in the road at last.
I need to have/get my bike repaired.
The mechanic said the car was so old it wasn't worth repairing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had my car repaired. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: to improve a bad situation
dictionaryExamples: It will take a long time to repair relations between the two countries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The German government was not able to repair the damage caused by the crisis. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: something that you do to fix something that is broken or damaged
dictionaryExamples: My car is in the garage for repairs.
The repairs to the roof will be expensive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father sent it to the workshop for repair. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to pay back money that you have borrowed
dictionaryExamples: He had to sell his car to repay the loan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could make a deal, so that I could repay my debts. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to do something kind for someone who has done something to help you
dictionaryExamples: What can I do to repay you for your kindness?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's always a ple[a]sure to see you and I hope I'll be able to repay your hospitality if you ever come to visit us in Cambridge. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to say or do something more than once
dictionaryExamples: He repeated the number.
The test must be repeated several times.
"I don't know!" he repeated.
Would you mind repeating what you just said?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to repeat that interesting visit. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to tell someone something that someone else has told you
dictionaryExamples: Please don't repeat what I've just told you to anyone else.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had written he was sorry, he should not have done it, he wished he had not repeated what I told him, he would never do something like that again... Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: done or happening more than once
dictionaryExamples: He refused repeated requests for an interviewed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were so many people and so many repeated questions and so much noise at home. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: many times
dictionaryExamples: He phoned the office repeatedly, hoping his package had been found.
He has repeatedly denied being there.
Educators have repeatedly stressed the benefits of learning a second language.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once you pick up the new words and learn something, you need to say it repeatedly otherwise you will easily forget [it]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: when you keep doing or saying something over again
dictionaryExamples: It takes time, patience, and repetition to learn a language.
We don't want a repetition of last year's disaster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This could in fact lead to a repetition of the mistakes of the past, when the paralyzed United Nations were, due to the small number and influence of neutral countries, a mere bystander to the risky arms-race fought out between the two nuclear superpowers. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: done or said in the same way several times, with nothing new added
dictionaryExamples: a repetitive job
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Chapters have turned repetitive and uninteresting, as nothing new happens. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to start using another thing or person instead of the one that you are using now
dictionaryExamples: We're thinking of replacing our old TV with a new one.
The factory replaced most of its workers with robots.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I'm going to replace the desk, because I [don't] have enough [sp]ace to put a computer onto it. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to get something new because the one you had before has been lost or damaged
dictionaryExamples: We'll have to replace this carpet soon.
I promised to replace the plate that I'd dropped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm very sorry about it [but] don't worry because I bought another one to replace it. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to start to be used instead of the thing or person that is being used now
dictionaryExamples: This system will replace the old one.
Tourism has replaced agriculture as the nation's main industry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We felt very disappointed when we discovered that Danny had been replaced by an unknown and really bad actor. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to put something back in the place where it usually is
dictionaryExamples: She picked up the books and carefully replaced them on the shelf.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jane jumped up and carefully replaced the photo on the desk. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the thing or person that replaces something or someone
dictionaryExamples: The agency sent a replacement for the secretary who resigned.
It's not going to be easy to find a replacement for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the people responsible for the concert did their best to find [a] replacement. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the process of replacing something with something else
dictionaryExamples: the replacement of existing computer equipment
replacement windows
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But by using much larger desks, we will be able to use the equipment more efficiently and this will reduce the cost for the replacement of broken equipment. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to answer
dictionaryExamples: "Where are you going?" I asked. "Home," he replied.
"I don't understand," she replied.
I replied that it was 12 o'clock.
He didn't reply to my e-mail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please reply as soon as possible. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: an answer
dictionaryExamples: Her reply was short and unfriendly.
Did you get a reply to your e-mail?
In reply to their questions, she just shrugged.
When he made no reply, she continued.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm waiting for your reply to tell me when [you] will come. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to describe a recent event or situation, especially on television, radio, or in a newspaper
dictionaryExamples: Jo Smith reports on recent developments.
She reported that the situation had changed dramatically.
A woman nearby reported seeing the accident.
The damage caused by the violent storm damage was reported on all the news programs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You reported that other performers were second-rate. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to tell someone in authority that something has happened, especially an accident or crime
dictionaryExamples: He should have reported the accident immediately.
Have you reported the problem to a technician?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course I reported it at the train station, but they couldn't find it [when] they s[ea]rched the train. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a description of an event or situation
dictionaryExamples: a news/weather report
a company's financial report
a report on climate change
According to reports there has been an earthquake in Los Angeles.
Remember to hand in your book reports on Tuesday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll be handing you a report [on] Chapter 7 the next day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: a teacher’s written statement about a student’s performance at school
dictionaryExamples: Sam got three As and a B on his report card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jone, I left my report card at your home. It is important to me because I have to show it to my parent[s]. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: according to what people say about something
dictionaryExamples: New York is reportedly a very exciting place to live.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some types of birds have reportedly become extinct in the area. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: someone whose job is to discover information about news events and describe them on television, radio, the Internet, or in a newspaper
dictionaryExamples: He's a reporter for the local newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reporters t[alke]d about her life, where she was born, [and] who her parents [are]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to be equal to something
dictionaryExamples: In practice the figure represents a 10% pay cut.
Approval of the subway extension represents commitment to development in this part of the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It [means] rec[y]cling 90% of the office material that we usually use. This represents a profit to the company which [would be] given to the employees, so they are motivated. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be the person from a country, school, etc., who is in a competition
dictionaryExamples: He was chosen to represent France at the Olympics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the age of 18, I started playing for my country.  I mean, I represent Mauritius in international matches. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to be a sign or symbol of something
dictionaryExamples: The knife-and-fork symbol on the map represents places serving food.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the sea represents life and the sacrifice[s] we [make]. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to officially speak or do something for someone else because they have asked you to
dictionaryExamples: The organization represents over professional basketball players.
They chose a famous lawyer to represent them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We hereby inform you that we have subsequently commen[c]ed proc[e]edings aimed at hiring a la[wy]er to represent our party in court, should such a step be necessary. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to show or describe someone or something in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: He represented himself as an expert, but his facts were all wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The innovative architecture would represent our everyday lives filled with work and technology. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the way someone or something is shown
dictionaryExamples: an accurate representation of country life
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mildred is an establishment pet, the representation of the current society they are living in. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: speaking or doing something officially for another person
dictionaryExamples: Can he afford legal representation?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An old politician whose name I do not recall once said "Taxation without representation is t[y]ranny" - nowadays this concept might be extended to corruption itself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: someone who speaks or does something officially for another person or group of people
dictionaryExamples: The company has representatives throughout South America.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mr Robertson, My name is ... and I am a student representative. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: criticism of someone, especially for not being successful or not doing what is expected
dictionaryExamples: There was a hint of reproach in his voice.
The article gave the impression that the teachers were above/beyond reproach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before they turned of[f] the light, he saw disappointment and reproach in their eyes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to criticize someone for not being successful or not doing what is expected
dictionaryExamples: You've no reason to reproach yourself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know I shouldn't reproach myself for not giving her money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to make a copy of something
dictionaryExamples: The diagram is reproduced by permission of the original author.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: MI5 operates two computers, one for word processing and another for scanning and reproducing prints, drawings and photos. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: to repeat something so that it is the same as before
dictionaryExamples: The new design unfortunately reproduced some of the problems of the earlier model.
We were unable to reproduce the results of our earlier research.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I overcame this by listening to tapes and by trying to reproduce the native speaker's sounds and stresses.  Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: If people, animals, or plants reproduce, they produce babies or young animals or plants.
dictionaryExamples: These organisms reproduce by dividing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Primitive man had a few aims in life like to be born, to reproduce and die, and among them there were two other important priorities, to hunt and to eat. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a copy of something, especially a painting
dictionaryExamples: The picture is a reproduction of a Manet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be great if the park provided some flight simulators and a reproduction of a space shuttle (so that people get a feeling of how it is to be an astronaut). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: the process of producing babies or young animals and plants
dictionaryExamples: We are learning about reproduction in biology.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What will happen if we live longer but we don't slow down the reproduction of our species? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: an animal that produces eggs and uses the heat of the sun to keep its blood warm
dictionaryExamples: Tom liked the reptiles, especially the snakes and the lizards.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The mainland's variable coast offers wonderful protection for all sorts of fish, sea mam[m]als or reptiles. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a country that is governed by elected representatives and an elected leader
dictionaryExamples: France is a republic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately in ancient Greece, although the notion of the republic and democracy were invented and quite successfully developed there, not being a noble citizen could be cruelly disappointing and painful. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: known to be good and honest
dictionaryExamples: a reputable organization
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe such a reputable company [as] you[rs] will not refuse to accept the responsibilities and prompt action will be taken in due course. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the opinion that people have about someone or something based on their behavior or character in the past
dictionaryExamples: The company has a worldwide reputation for quality.
Both hotels have a good reputation.
He  quickly earned a reputation as an entertaining speaker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My country has a great reputation for food. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when you politely or officially ask for something
dictionaryExamples: They received hundreds of requests for more information.
He made a request for the report to be sent to his doctor.
An application form is available on request.
The clause was added to the contract at her request.
The manager refused their request to leave work early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I decided to reply [to] your request as soon as possible. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to politely or officially ask for something
dictionaryExamples: We've requested two more computers.
They requested that no photographs be taken in the museum.
Visitors are requested not to walk on the grass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to rent a car [at the] Hertz agency and request information about where the hotel [i]s. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to need or demand something
dictionaryExamples: If you require assistance with your bags, I’ll be glad to get someone to help you.
A building permit is required.
Training to be a doctor requires a lot of hard work.
Call this number if you require more information.
Skiing down a steep slope requires total concentration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Weddings are very different in our country and require a lot of [prepara]tion. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to officially demand that someone does something
dictionaryExamples: You are required by law to produce a valid passport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It may occur in the future that they are required to posses[s] knowledge of something they didn't study at school in order to get a job. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian
