sense.def: something that you must do, or something you need
dictionaryExamples: A college degree is a minimum requirement for many jobs.
Valid insurance is a legal requirement.
Students who fail to meet the requirements of the course will fail.
college entrance requirements
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have any more requirements, please don't hesitate to contact me. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: to change the time of an event or meeting
dictionaryExamples: I rescheduled my doctor’s appointment for later in the week.
Can we reschedule the meeting for Monday?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He will come next Friday morning, if [that does not suit you just call him and reschedule the appointment. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to save someone from a dangerous or unpleasant situation
dictionaryExamples: Fifty passengers had to be rescued from a sinking ship.
The government has refused to rescue the company from bankruptcy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A bomb had exploded and that boy rescued me from the accident. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: when someone is saved from a dangerous or unpleasant situation
dictionaryExamples: Lifeboats carry out many rescues every month.
an unsuccessful rescue attempt
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last Friday I saw one that was about two guys  who were lost in the jungle for nine days, and the rescue team found them alive. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to help someone who is in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: I forgot my purse but Anna came to the rescue and lent me some money.

sense.def: the study of a subject in detail to find information or to gain a better understanding of it
dictionaryExamples: scientific/medical research
a research center
research on language development
I like doing research.
I've done some research on the best beaches to visit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have been doing research about how well people dress, and I think I dress with care. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to study a subject in detail or to try to find information about a subject
dictionaryExamples: He spent several years researching a rare African dialect.
She's researching possible cures for malaria.
He went online to research flights and hotels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to write an article [called] Protect our Environment so I researched and studied a lot about it using [the] Internet and [the] library to find suitable details. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: someone who does research as a job
dictionaryExamples: Researchers uncovered new facts about his family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As researchers find out more about animals, we learn more about them and because of this we learn more about the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a similarity between two people or things, especially in their appearance
dictionaryExamples: There's a striking resemblance between Diane and her mother.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must admit that Dick has a strong resemblance to Neolithic Man, but everyone loves him because he is so cheerful and talkative. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrase: bear a/little/no, etc. resemblance to sth/sb

sense.def: to be similar/not similar/somewhat similar, etc., to something or someone
dictionaryExamples: He bears   a resemblance to someone I used to know.
The city bears little resemblance to how it was 100 years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The concert bore no resemblance to any other I have been to, firstly due to the location, and secondly thanks to the spontaneity, yet impressive precision of the performance - the two factors which created the unique atmosphere of the event.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to look like or be like someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She resembles her father.
After the earthquake, the city resembled a battlefield.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, the most representative Romanian resorts resemble the ones in the Alps and maybe even exceed them in the respect of popularity among all walks of life and affordability. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to feel angry and upset about a situation or about something that someone has done
dictionaryExamples: I resent having to work late.
He resents the fact that she gets more money than he does.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More specifically, my cousin's husband and his family, neither of whom I knew very well, deeply resented this decision. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a feeling of anger about a situation that you think is unfair
dictionaryExamples: If you treat your staff differently, it just causes resentment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was pleased by the variety of opinions presented; some of the writers expressed a blind faith that we can still learn from our previous mistakes, while others approached the subject with a surprising resentment of our past. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Czech

sense.def: an arrangement that you make to have a seat on an aircraft, a room in a hotel, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I made a reservation at the restaurant for 7 o’clock.
Please confirm your reservation two days in advance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can make a reservation if you want. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a doubt or a feeling that you do not accept or agree with something completely
dictionaryExamples: I still have reservations about her ability to do the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their families agreed to that, but with certain reservations, as they saw it quite soon to [take] such an important step. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to arrange to have a seat on an aircraft, a room in a hotel, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I’m sorry, this seat is reserved.
It’s a popular restaurant, and you’ll have to reserve well in advance.
I reserved a room at the Lamb Hotel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can reserve the tickets. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to not allow people to use something because it is only for a particular person or for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: This space is reserved for ambulances only.
These seats are reserved for the elderly and the disabled.
He reserved the right to veto any future plans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can also use streets reserved for walker[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: ready to be used if or when you need it
dictionaryExamples: She keeps a little money in reserve.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be an idea to have some activity in reserve if you have to cancel something, such as the boat trip on the Thames. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a supply of something that you keep until it is needed
dictionaryExamples: emergency cash reserves
I have a reserve of canned food in case of emergency.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dependence on oil is a menace because oil reserves will disappear and because at this time we have no other invention to replace it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: describes people who keep their feelings or thoughts private rather than showing them
dictionaryExamples: Marcus is more reserved than his brother.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was shy, reserved and a very closed person. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a building where someone lives
dictionaryExamples: That big building is the governor's official residence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just a short stroll away there is a former King’s residence, Wawel Castle. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: someone who lives in a particular place
dictionaryExamples: a resident of New York/the UK/Brazil
Local residents were angry at the lack of parking spaces.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will have less anxious residents in cities, who will not hurry to go to work or will not be late home or at the office. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: A residential area has only houses and not offices or factories.
dictionaryExamples: It's a largely residential area with one or two small stores.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Varta" is situated in a quiet residential area and could be called  "a family restaurant." First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to officially tell your employer that you are leaving your job
dictionaryExamples: He resigned as chairman of the committee.
Two directors have resigned from the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So Laura stepped into her boss'[s] office, wished him a Merry Christmas and resigned. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to make yourself accept something that you do not like because you cannot easily change it
dictionaryExamples: He resigned himself to living alone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally I wouldn't like to be at the age when you can't afford anything except bread and butter and you have to resign yourself to this miserable existence without any hope for [a] brighter future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when someone tells their employer that they are leaving their job
dictionaryExamples: a letter of resignation
I handed in my resignation yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had been so proud of herself no more than five minutes ago walking out of the editor's office after handing him her letter of resignation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: when you accept something that you do not like because you cannot easily change it
dictionaryExamples: She accepted her illness with calm resignation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He sighed with resignation and got up. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the ability  improve quickly after being hurt or being ill
dictionaryExamples: She had the resilience to try again.
Life is hard there, but the people are resilient.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their resilience had been pushed to the extreme and, but for their sheer longing for a child, they might have given up. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: strong enough to get better quickly after damage, disappointment, illness, shock, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Growth figures show that the economy is still fairly resilient.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He could not stand the thought of staying away from Bill, he was not that resilient. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to stop yourself from doing something that you want to do
dictionaryExamples: I can't resist chocolate.
I couldn't resist laughing at that silly ad.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How do we resist all these nice snacks, and stay slim? First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to fight against something or someone that is attacking you
dictionaryExamples: Students want to discover the truth themselves, and they resist having conclusions forced on them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Turkish ci[v]ilization was poorer than [the] Greek ci[v]ilisation and that is one more reason why [the] Greeks had to resist and fight their enemies. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when people disagree with a change, idea, etc. and refuse to accept it
dictionaryExamples: resistance to political change
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only resistance comes from Jack, an aggressive and impetuous boy who places facts higher than speech[e]s. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when someone fights against someone who is attacking them or competing against them
dictionaryExamples: She didn't put up much resistance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their knowledge helped Hitler to prolong his resistance against the overwhelming superiority of the Allies. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: an organization that secretly fights against an enemy that has taken control of its country
dictionaryExamples: She was active in the resistance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite the fact that [the] Germans were many and much more powerful, they faced many difficulties from the Greek resistance. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the ability of your body to not be affected by illnesses
dictionaryExamples: Cold weather may lower the body's resistance to infection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His physical resistance is exceptional, he is young, in perfect condition, healthy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the solution to a problem
dictionaryExamples: a successful resolution to the crisis
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It might help us to find alternative conflict resolutions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: an official decision that is made after a group or organization has voted
dictionaryExamples: Congress passed a resolution in support of the plan.
Our branch has submitted a resolution on housing to the conference.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: India declared that the UN resolution about the ban on nuclear weapons [wa]s unfair. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a promise to yourself to do something
dictionaryExamples: My New Year's resolution is to do more exercise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a New Year's resolution I decided to save some money in a jar for my husband. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to solve or end a problem or difficulty
dictionaryExamples: an attempt to resolve the dispute
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would very much like to suggest a meeting, in order to resolve some of the issues. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: when you are very determined to do something
dictionaryExamples: The training was tough, but his resolve never wavered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Daniella's attention was focused on the scene and she was truly enjoying what was going on. This sight toughened Marco's resolve. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a place where many people go on vacation or for an activity they enjoy
dictionaryExamples: a beach resort
a ski resort
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We stayed one week in a chalet near the ski resort. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: something that you do because everything else has failed
dictionaryExamples: As a last resort, we could ask your mother to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a last resort and a solution for those that don't admire books, I would recommend b[u]ying a comic [in] which you see more pictures than words. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to do something in order to achieve what you want, because it is the only thing you can do to achieve it
dictionaryExamples: I had to resort to threats to get my money back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is caused by a person's basic need for food: If someone can't get enough to eat he might have to resort to stealing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: something useful that a country, person, or organization has which they can use
dictionaryExamples: natural resources
The library was a valuable resource, and he frequently made use of it.
Local mineral resources include oil, coal and gas deposits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With all the resources on the Net, I don't need to go to the library as often as I used to. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: good at finding ways to solve problems
dictionaryExamples: When we didn't have much money, we had to be more resourceful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The tormentor was inventive, clever, resourceful and learned fast how to make the most ordinary objects (a moth, a crow) into a source of overwhelming fear for his victim. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: when you admire someone because of their knowledge, skill, or achievements
dictionaryExamples: She's an excellent teacher and I have the greatest respect for her.
New teachers have to earn the respect of their students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to improve my English, [and] there the teachers are respected and listen to the pupils. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: when you are polite to someone, especially because they are older or more important than you
dictionaryExamples: You should show more respect for your parents.
Teachers should be treated with respect.
She has no respect for her boss.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for people who attend weddings, it's important for them to wear formal clothes to show their respect [for] the new couple. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: in particular ways
dictionaryExamples: In some respects, I had to admit, I had behaved foolishly.
The school has changed in many respects.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How's your friend Mike? He is in many respects better than [a] computer, isn't he? (Teasing you again, sorry). First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: relating to a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: Before we move on, are there any more questions with respect to the treasurer's report?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With respect to the ages of the members, they are between fifteen and twenty years old. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to politely disagree with or give a negative opinion about something
dictionaryExamples: I’ve been thinking about what you said and, with all due respect, I think you’re mistaken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally we would like to point out two [things] that should be improved. The first one is entertainment, which, with all due respect, is very poor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to admire someone because of their knowledge, achievements, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I respect him for his honesty.
I deeply respect David for what he has achieved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's nice to have a friend who respects you and who you respect too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: If you respect someone's rights, customs, wishes, etc. you accept their importance and are careful not to do anything they would not want.
dictionaryExamples: If you decide to do otherwise we will, of course, respect your wishes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the situation is getting worse because of the decisions of the European Union, which is trying to unif[y] Europe[an] education without respecting the wishes of the students, who are trying to stop this process. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: behaving in a socially acceptable way or looking socially acceptable
dictionaryExamples: a respectable family
a respectable hotel
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But no [o]ne could think of a respectable doctor poisoning two of his patients, which is what he actually did. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: large enough or good enough
dictionaryExamples: She earns a respectable salary.
The final score was a respectable 2 to1.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we had to wait until he could confidently say to his parents, "Look, I am an adult now, and I'm working for a large company with a respectable job, and I am going to get married if I want to." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: admired by people because of your knowledge, achievements, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a highly respected doctor/politician
He is very well respected in the business world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Looking at Pele's life, we discover that he was a respected man who did his [be]st to help others and his country. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: showing respect for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: They treated us in a very respectful manner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Were I not respectful of your work, I would say that your reporter did not attend this event and just imagined it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: in a way that shows respect for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: He always spoke to them very respectfully.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I respectfully request you, as a store manager, to personally look into this situation, assist in investigating the problem with the faulty equipment as [a] matter of urgency by sending round a qualified engineer and, if found unfixable, arrange for a new unit to be supplied. International English Language Testing System; C2; Azerbaijani

sense.def: relating to each of the people or things that you have just talked about
dictionaryExamples: Barkley and Jordan are the two best players on their respective teams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Relatives and friends of the respective families were very successful in being guides for some hours. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: in a way that relates to each of the people or things that you have just talked about
dictionaryExamples: They scored 10 and 17 points, respectively.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only [did] we reach our target figure but also, 85% of the revenue generated went to the hospital, and only 10% and 5% were for entertainment costs and administration costs, respectively. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to say or do something as a reaction to something that has been said or done
dictionaryExamples: To every question, he responded "I don't know."
I asked her what the time was, but she didn't respond.
The government has responded by sending food and medical supplies to the region.
How did she respond to the news?
The police respond to emergencies  in just a few minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The two men didn't respond so David closed the door. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an answer or reaction to something that has been said or done
dictionaryExamples: Responses to our advertisement have been disappointing.
The dean's comments provoked an angry response from students.
Her proposals met with an enthusiastic response.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The telephone] is an easy way to contact others, better than writing a letter and waiting for a response. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: as an answer or reaction to
dictionaryExamples:
The law was passed by the town council in response to 
 
                   complaints from residents.
I'm writing in response to your letter of February 14th.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing in response to your advertisement, which appeared in the newspaper on November the 23rd, looking for a person to work at weekends in your café. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something that it is your job or duty to deal with
dictionaryExamples: The head of the department has various additional responsibilities.
It is your responsibility to make sure that your homework is done on time.
She takes her responsibilities as a nurse very seriously.
Jenny, you have responsibility for clearing up the room after the class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is the country's responsibility to supply the schools with everything needed. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to say that you have done something or caused something to happen, especially something bad
dictionaryExamples: The company took full responsibility for the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes he just take[s] all the responsibility for the projects, which he should not do, at least not alone. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to relax or sleep because you are tired after an activity or because you are ill
dictionaryExamples: The doctor told him that he should rest for a few days.
Pete's resting after his long drive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather was particularly sunny there, so we decided to eat an ice-cream and to rest a little. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to stop using your eyes/feet/legs, etc. for a while because they are tired
dictionaryExamples: He looked away from the computer screen to rest his eyes.

sense.def: If something rests somewhere, or if you rest it somewhere, it is supported by something else.
dictionaryExamples: She rested her elbows on the table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This masterpiece, painted in shocking colors on an enormous canvas, shows an Indian, completely out of proportion, sitting on the ground and resting his head on his arms. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the part of something that remains, or the others that remain
dictionaryExamples: Two students are in the library and the rest are in the classroom.
I'll keep a third of the money and the rest is for you.
Do you have anything planned for the rest of the day?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bring a pencil and some paper, the teacher will give us the rest of the material. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a period of time when you relax or sleep
dictionaryExamples: Why don't you take a rest?
I have to get some rest.
After walking a few miles, we stopped for a rest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My doctor told me that I should get more rest. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: to start something again that had stopped
dictionaryExamples: They want to restart the talks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, acco[r]ding to our recent survey, the company is getting [into a] better situation than it was beginning of this year and wants to restart trading with us. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: If you restart a computer, you turn it off and then on again.
dictionaryExamples: Try restarting your computer.

sense.def: a place where you can buy and eat a meal
dictionaryExamples:
We had lunch at/in a 
                         restaurant near the station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes I'm very tired bec[a]use I work in [a] restaurant. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: unable to be still or relax because you are bored or nervous
dictionaryExamples: The audience was getting restless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children are restless and they like to play and want to have fun all the time, even when they are flying. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: not satisfied with what you are doing now and wanting something new
dictionaryExamples: The opposition parties provide no clear alternative for restless voters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She yearned for something different from her day-to-day life and grew increasingly restless. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to repair and clean something old
dictionaryExamples: The badly neglected paintings have all been carefully restored.
He restores antique furniture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, the old church could be restored, to be as beautiful as it used to be. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to make something good exist again
dictionaryExamples: Three wins in a row helped restore the team's confidence.
Peace has now been restored in the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would also restore our confidence in our paper if the correct version of events were printed, together with your statement of apology. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to control the actions or behavior of someone, sometimes by using force
dictionaryExamples: He became violent and had to be physically restrained.
I had to restrain myself from shouting at him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is sadly true, that we, from time to time, find it difficult to restrain our vivacious spirits. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: calm and controlled behavior
dictionaryExamples: He showed admirable restraint and refused to be provoked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In his [opinion], a really professional butler should pos[s]ess "dignity," which means that he should not expose his feelings and should always be capable of emotional restraint even if he is being provoked by something very surprising, alarming or vexing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to limit something
dictionaryExamples: The state legislature voted to restrict development in the area.
I restrict myself to one cup of coffee a day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We must try to restrict the use of water in agriculture. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: controlled or limited
dictionaryExamples: Many events are free, so families on restricted budgets can participate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for things I personally do not like is, first of all, the restricted hours of library availability. International English Language Testing System; C1; Russian

sense.def: a situation or event that limits what people can do
dictionaryExamples: For the first time, I could do exactly what I wanted, without any restrictions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When people travel on their own, they can do what they want, without restrictions or limitations from their family. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a rule or law  that limits or controls what people can do
dictionaryExamples: speed/parking restrictions
There are restrictions on what goods you can bring into the country.
The president urged other countries to lift the trade restrictions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our world is becoming smaller and smaller: boundaries are erased from the maps, countries cooperate more intensively, and trade restrictions are falling away. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: limiting activities too much
dictionaryExamples: restrictive practices
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, being too restrictive may result in making the children passive, [causing them to] take everything for granted and leav[ing] them completely unprepared for the harsh reality of life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a room or small building in a public place in which there are several toilets
dictionaryExamples: Do you know where the restroom is?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They reached the airport at 8:45 p.m. The flight was to take off at 11:30 p.m. So Lucy's father went to use the restroom. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to organize a system or organization in a new way
dictionaryExamples: They are restructuring the business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, the globali[z]ation and merging trends are creating industrial giants that regularly have to restructure in order to minimi[z]e their production costs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: something that happens or exists because something else has happened
dictionaryExamples: Most accidents are the result of human error.
Unemployment has risen as a direct result of new economic policies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, I am a bit cold now. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: information that you get from something such as an exam, a scientific experiment, or a medical test
dictionaryExamples: She's waiting for the results of a blood test.
the results of a survey
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tim was my manager and he had promised me to write as soon as he was able to find out the music quiz results. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the score or number of votes at the end of a competition or election
dictionaryExamples: Election results are beginning  to come in.
What was the result of this afternoon's game?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The[y] were all so surprised about the result of [the] game Germany against Saudi Arabia that they welcom[ed me] in a very friendly way. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to cause a particular situation to happen
dictionaryExamples: The fire resulted in damage to their property.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has resulted in a lack of repair services. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If an activity resumes, or if you resume it, it starts again after a pause.
dictionaryExamples: The talks are due to resume today.
Normal services will be resumed in the spring.
He stopped to take a sip of water and then resumed speaking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope our two companies can resume their excellent cooperation in the future and I am looking forward to using one of your aircraft again. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a document that describes your education, qualifications and the jobs you have done, which you send to an employer who you want to work for
dictionaryExamples: If you wish to apply, please send your résumé and a cover letter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you will see from my enclosed resume, I graduated from Faculty of Education in the Chinese University of Hong Kong and I worked in a child care cent[er] for three years. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the sale of products to customers for their own use, usually in stores
dictionaryExamples: jobs in retail
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I work in retail and I know how important [it] is to work with your team. 
 International English Language Testing System; C1; Pashto

sense.def: involving or related to the sale of products to customers for their own use
dictionaryExamples: Retail sales are rising.
retail stores/outlets
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is important to have contin[u]ous retail sales for any economy to function. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: someone who sells products to the public
dictionaryExamples: Retailers claim the new sales tax will hurt business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They claim that retailers and advertisers brainwash us into buying more than necessary. International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to continue to keep something
dictionaryExamples: Francis retained control of the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, one might claim, this could also be good, as people retain their local customs, lifestyle, etc. and do not have the anxiety or stress of living in cities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the ability to keep or continue having something
dictionaryExamples: Officials are focusing on job creation, not job retention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Additional audio and video inputs allows easier assimilation and retention of this information. International English Language Testing System; C2; Bengali

sense.def: to change what you think about something or what you plan to do
dictionaryExamples: We've had to rethink our strategy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are some points to be rethought, although the proposed plan was generally accepted. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to leave your job and stop working, usually because you are old
dictionaryExamples: She retired from the company in 1990.
He is due to retire as chief executive next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays I'm free because I retired recently. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: having stopped working, often because you are old
dictionaryExamples: Both my parents are retired.
He is a retired airline pilot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This person is a retired soldier who fought during World War II. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you leave your job and stop working, usually because you are old
dictionaryExamples: Many teachers over the age of 50 are taking early retirement.
What is the normal retirement age in this country?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Pamela, I really like you and am happy [about] our sharing the same office but I'm afraid that, because of your way of life, you will never reach the age of retirement. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the period of your life after you have stopped working
dictionaryExamples: We wish you a long and happy retirement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before my retirement, I spent some 11 years in the U.S., Germany and Switzerland where I learn[ed] a lot about the different culture[s] and people's customs and manners. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to get  something after first finding it
dictionaryExamples: Important historic documents were retrieved from a from a storage room last week.
We're teaching our dog to retrieve a ball thrown in the pond.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I have to make a credit decision, I retrieve the relevant industry analysis report in order to obtain a better understanding of the industry of the borrower. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to go or come back to a place where you were before
dictionaryExamples: He returned to Nigeria in 2009.
She'll return home from a business trip tomorrow.
She left Sweden at the age of 25 and never returned.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She will return to Turkey next Friday. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to give, send, or put something back where it came from
dictionaryExamples: I have to return the book by Friday.
He immediately returned the records to the files.
The new TV broke so they returned it to the store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can you return it to me, please? Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to start doing an activity again or talking about something again
dictionaryExamples: I returned to work three months after Susie was born.
We keep returning to the same subject.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [In] August I must return to school, so I can only go to California in July. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to happen again  or start to exist again
dictionaryExamples: You should call the doctor if the pain returns.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This made her calm down all of a sudden, and her voice returned. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to react to something that someone does or says by doing or saying the same
dictionaryExamples: I returned his smile.
I have to return Michael's call.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the meeting he told me that this was the reason why he likes to work with me - thereby he returned the motivation that I gave to him. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to go back to the usual condition
dictionaryExamples: Life has begun to return to normal now that the holidays are over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After exactly ten minutes the electricity was switched on again and our life returned to normal - what a relief! First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when someone goes or comes back to a place where they were before
dictionaryExamples: The whole town came out to celebrate his return from the war.
On his return to Sydney, he started up a business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But on the return from Zurich we had a[n] accident and the car has been destroyed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: a key on a computer keyboard that is used to make the computer accept information or to start a new line in a document
dictionaryExamples: Type in the password and press return.

sense.def: in exchange for something or as a reaction to something
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to give them something in return for everything they've done for us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a great time and in return I'd love to invite you to live at my house, while you are in Poland. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: an occasion when people meet together again, often after a long time
dictionaryExamples: a family/school reunion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the former students where left with a lot of good memories, which was clearly shown a few months ago when we organized a reunion of the old B class, the number of people present was double what was expected. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to give someone a piece of information that is surprising or that was previously secret
dictionaryExamples: He was jailed for revealing secrets to the Russians.
It was revealed in this morning's papers that the couple intend to marry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I immediately knew that something was wrong so I had a word with Pat. She denied having revealed my secret. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to allow something to be seen that, until then, had been hidden
dictionaryExamples: X-rays revealed that my ribs had been cracked but not broken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she was walking down the street feeling elated by the success of the business meeting, a gorgeous thirtyish man wearing [a] beige polo neck swiftly appro[a]ched and turned toward her and smiled, revealing strong white teeth. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a piece of information that is discovered although it was intended to be kept secret
dictionaryExamples: He resigned following revelations about his private life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No, the mayor didn't know, but said he was looking forward to any more revelations about their heroic community member. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to be an extremely pleasant surprise
dictionaryExamples: Anna's musical talent was a revelation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every word you said was a revelation to me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: something that you do to punish someone who has done something bad to you
dictionaryExamples: He's made life very difficult for me but I'll get/take my revenge.
He was looking for revenge against those who had helped oust him from his leadership position.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lew Kuan Yee had sworn revenge against Michael, the detective who had sent him behind bars. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: income received by a business or government or the amount of this income
dictionaryExamples: state/federal revenues
Revenue was up in the last quarter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both the coffee bar and the shop will generate revenue, be self-sufficient and, more importantly, cr[e]ate jobs for the college students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: a change to the opposite position, direction or order of something
dictionaryExamples: In a significant reversal of earlier trends, people are moving back to Salt Lake City.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, more and more people will become aware of the existing situation and contribute to its reversal. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to change a situation or change the order of things so that it becomes the opposite
dictionaryExamples: Now that you have a job and I don't, our situations are reversed.
It is unlikely that the judge will reverse his decision.
Let's reverse the order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This trend should be reversed in the near future. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: in the opposite order or way
dictionaryExamples: Now go through the steps in reverse to take the bookcase apart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They want to see what they are not like, how they would not react and this, in reverse, helps them [to] find themselves. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the method for driving a vehicle that makes it go backward
dictionaryExamples: Put the car in/into reverse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a last good look around and then I returned to the car and put it into reverse. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If something is reversible, it can be changed back to what it was before.
dictionaryExamples: Most of the damage done to the cells is reversible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The friendship that I thought was [for] life stopped somewhere and somehow in [an] unexpected way, which didn't allow us to make the situation reversible. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: Reversible clothes can be worn so that the inside is the outside.
dictionaryExamples: a reversible jacket

sense.def: to study a subject before you take a test
dictionaryExamples: She spent half the night reviewing her notes for the French test.
There will be time in class tomorrow to review before the quiz.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What am I going to review for [the] exam? Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: to give your opinion in a report about a book, film, television program, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He reviews movies for the local paper.

sense.def: to consider something again in order to decide if changes should be made
dictionaryExamples: Officials have to review the text before it’s made public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand I would like to ask you kindly to review my conditions of employment and to take in consideration my expenses, which I think would be more than correct. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: a report in a newspaper, magazine, or program that gives an opinion about a new book, film, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He writes movie/theater/book reviews for the newspapers.
Her latest novel had/received excellent reviews.
The film has had mixed reviews.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was thinking we should see "Show Bar," the review is good! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the study you do to learn about a subject or before a test
dictionaryExamples: The teacher devoted the last week of the semester to  review
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll be in an exam review on Tuesday at 11:00am, so I was thinking if we can change our meeting, the same day, just a little bit later, if you don't mind we could meet us at the Italian restaurant at 3:00pm. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the process of considering something again in order to make changes to it
dictionaryExamples: a review of teachers' pay
The organizational structure is under review.

sense.def: to change something so that it is more accurate or better than before
dictionaryExamples: His publishers made him revise his manuscript three times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I advi[s]e you to revise your schedule. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when something becomes more active or popular again
dictionaryExamples: a revival in folk music
Yoga is enjoying a revival.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In recent years the fear of society has led to a revival of conservative ideas that want to shift responsibility for this kind of education back to the family unit. International English Language Testing System; C2; German

sense.def: to make something from the past exist again
dictionaryExamples: to revive memories
A lot of traditional skills are currently being revived.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why not revive the "good old" reading sessions we had in many town libraries in the 70s and 80s? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to try to change a government, often using violence, or to refuse to accept someone's authority
dictionaryExamples: Many were killed when nationalists revolted against the new government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What often happens, if money is the substitute for love, is that children revolt against their parents. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to think that something is extremely unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: They were revolted by conditions on the farm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are revolted by Olivia's decision which also shows the condescending opinion they have of the Nawab. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a change in the way a country is governed, usually to a different political system and often involving violence or war
dictionaryExamples: The French Revolution changed France from a monarchy to a republic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's supposed to be read as a study [of] the Soviet dictatorship during the October revolution and beyond into the Cold War era. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a very important change in the way that people do things
dictionaryExamples: a technological revolution
Penicillin produced a revolution in medicine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The technological revolution taking place today can be directly linked to the amazing evolution of our communication abilities throughout th[e]se last years. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: completely different from what was done before
dictionaryExamples: The twentieth century brought about revolutionary changes in our lifestyles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe my ideas are too revolutionary but ... I think in this way Torino would be NICER! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: involved in or relating to a revolution
dictionaryExamples: a revolutionary leader/movement

sense.def: something good that you get or experience because you have worked hard, behaved well, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There'll be a reward for whoever finishes first.
I told her she could choose a toy as a reward for her good behavior.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  A TV company chose our school for a program!  We won a contest with a surprise reward, and that was it! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: an amount of money given to someone for helping to find something or for helping the police to return stolen property
dictionaryExamples: The police offered a reward for any information about the robbery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And as a reward, my father took out RM500 and gave it to the bystander. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to give someone a reward
dictionaryExamples: She was rewarded for her bravery.
The company rewarded him for his years of service with a gold watch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was so happy afterwards and was even rewarded with a medal. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: making you feel satisfied that you have done something well or done something helpful
dictionaryExamples: a rewarding experience
Teaching is hard work but it's very rewarding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I led a workshop with children, which was a very rewarding experience, and performed for people of all ages and backgrounds. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to write something again in order to improve it
dictionaryExamples: I had to rewrite my essay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I trust you will give this matter your immediate atten[t]ion and rewrite your report using the information given. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If a word rhymes with another word, the end part of the words sound the same.
dictionaryExamples: "Moon" rhymes with "June."

sense.def: a short poem that has words ending in the same sound at the end of the lines
dictionaryExamples: The card contained a short rhyme.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It gives a child immense pleasure when her parent reads out a rhyme or a story to her. International English Language Testing System; C2; Bengali

sense.def: a style of writing or speaking that uses words that end with the same sound
dictionaryExamples: The story was written entirely in rhyme.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The poem had no rhyme and it had a free verse form. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a regular, repeating pattern of sound or movement
dictionaryExamples: He beat out a jazz rhythm on the drums.
I've got no sense of rhythm, so I'm a terrible dancer.
She lay back in the boat, feeling the gentle rhythm of the waves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From then on I have been suffering from high blood pressure and disturbances of the rhythm of the heart-beat. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: one of the curved bones in the chest
dictionaryExamples: He cracked a rib in the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stayed there for 2 weeks with a broken leg, sore ribs and a couple of scars. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a long, narrow piece of cloth that is used for tying things or used for decoration
dictionaryExamples: Her hair was tied with a velvet ribbon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just a week before, the wedding family and close friends come together to decorate the tent with special hand-folded ribbons. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian

sense.def: small grains from a plant that are cooked and eaten
dictionaryExamples: boiled/fried rice
Do you prefer brown or white rice?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like rice and fish. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali

sense.def: having much more money than most people, or owning things that could be sold for a lot of money
dictionaryExamples: She's from a very rich family.
He's the third richest man in the country.
They're one of the world's richest nations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got many CDs, DVDs and clothes, but the best [present] was a 72" Plasma television that I received from our rich friend, Richie Rich. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: Rich food has a lot of fat, oil or eggs in it.
dictionaryExamples: a rich sauce
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The cooking [is] bas[ed] on traditional recipes of Westfalian origin and it is tasty but often very rich! First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: containing a lot of something that is important or valuable
dictionaryExamples: The region is rich in minerals and coal deposits.
Both foods are rich in Vitamin C.
The country has vast oil reserves and rich deposits of other minerals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their lessons are valuable, rich in knowledge and fun[n]y. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: people who are rich
dictionaryExamples: These ski resorts are for the rich.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What did the rich do all day? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a lot of money or valuable objects
dictionaryExamples: To her, $500 seemed like untold riches.
oil/mineral riches
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First, her career can be regarded as the typical rise from "rags to riches." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the interesting or impressive quality of something that shows how strong or varied it is
dictionaryExamples: I was amazed by  the richness of their traditions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cultures of Mexico: You will be able to discover the richness and variety of Mexican ancient cultures: - Mexica - Maya - Olmeca - Tolteca - Zapoteca - Chichimeca. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to travel by sitting on a horse, bicycle, or motorcycle and controlling it
dictionaryExamples: I learned to ride a bike when I was four.
I ride my bicycle to work.
I've ridden on a donkey.
My aunt kept horses and she taught me to ride.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like rid[ing] my bike in Gloucester. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to travel in a vehicle, such as a car, bus or train
dictionaryExamples: We rode the train from Sydney to Perth.

sense.def: a trip in a vehicle or train
dictionaryExamples: It's a short bus ride to the airport.
Can I give you a ride to the station?
He asked me for a ride into town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the next day, I went swimming in the lake early in the morning and took a bus ride home after that. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a trip you take by riding a bicycle, motorcycle, or horse
dictionaryExamples: He's gone out for a ride on his bike.
Do you want to come for a ride on my motorbike?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I swam in the sea, sunba[th]ed on the golden beach and had a ride on [a] scooter. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: a machine at a fair  that moves people up and down, around in circles, etc., as they sit in it
dictionaryExamples: She wanted me to go on a ride with her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recommend visits [to] the beaches because there are different rides, boating and m[uch] more available. Preliminary English Test; B1; Gujarati

sense.def: someone who rides a horse, bicycle, or motorcycle
dictionaryExamples: One of the riders was thrown off his horse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A lot of good riders will come with their horses to take p[art] in a competition. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: very silly
dictionaryExamples: I'd look ridiculous in a hat like that.
"The post office won't forward my mail." "That's ridiculous! Why not?"
It's a ridiculous idea/suggestion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, it is just ridiculous to hear that there were fewer than 2000 people there. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: correct or true
dictionaryExamples: He only got half the answers right.
You're right about Alison - she's great!
"You came here in 1979, didn't you?" "That's right."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You're right! Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: on or toward the side of your body that is to the east when you are facing north

sense.def: immediately

sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: As soon as I saw the handwriting on the envelope I smiled.  
 I recognized it right away. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: correctly
dictionaryExamples: He guessed right most of the time.

sense.def: the right side of your body, or the direction toward this side

sense.def: used to express agreement with someone
dictionaryExamples: "Johnny, you climb up first."  "Right!"

sense.def: on or to the right of something

sense.def: supporting limited economic controls, private property and wealth, and limited government

sense.def: a round piece of jewelry that you wear on your finger

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sammy gave me a gold ring, Remi an orange swe[a]ter, Minny a bag and Dominique a red cap. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: extremely colorful and bright

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to move up
dictionaryExamples: The balloon rose up into the air.

sense.def: to increase in level

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

                         the root of all evil.
