sense.def: Rotten vegetable or animal substances are decaying.
dictionaryExamples: rotten eggs/fruit
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll tell you something - my freezer still smells of rotten fish. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: A rough surface is not smooth.
dictionaryExamples: rough ground
It was a rough mountain road, covered in stones and huge holes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went with some people I know from bike competitions, and I [was] impressed with how well they can ride a bike on rough terrain, w[hile] I had to go carefully in some tracks. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: approximate and not exact
dictionaryExamples: Write a rough copy first and check the grammar.
Can you give me a rough idea of the numbers?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I lost my personal notepad where I used to write all my job tasks, my arrangements and the records of my students.  I have [even] written the rough copy of some personal letters [there]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: If the sea or weather is rough, there is a lot of strong wind and sometimes rain.
dictionaryExamples: The boat sank in rough waters/seas off the coast of Maine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I never saw a landscape similar to the Ring of Kerry before: breathtaking views, the rough sea to the right, peaceful gaps to the left - great! First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: difficult or unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: She's having a rough time at work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He did the mountain-route last year and he says that even he had a rough time. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: dangerous or violent
dictionaryExamples: a rough part of town
Hockey can be a rough game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I were able to travel back in History, I would choose to go to France during the French Revolution. I think it would be very interesting to see how people can be really devoted and can fight when they see they are being cheated.  I know it was a very rough and dangerous time, but it must have been really exciting. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: approximately
dictionaryExamples: There has been an increase of roughly 2.25 million.
Roughly speaking, it's 2.25 million.
We have roughly the same tastes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These are very special cases and roughly speaking, confined to one thing. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: forcefully or violently
dictionaryExamples: He pushed us roughly out of the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother treated me roughly and unkindly by thrashing or smacking me a[t] any time possible. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: without taking a lot of care to make something perfect
dictionaryExamples: Roughly chop the tomatoes and add to the onions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She glanced at the mirror, roughly [brushed] her hair with her fingers and went outside for her car. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: in the shape of a circle or ball
dictionaryExamples: a round hole/stone/table/window
a round face
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is on the round table in your room. Key English Test; A2; Kannada

sense.def: the first/second/third/final, etc. stage in a competition
dictionaryExamples: He was beaten in the first round.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At five o'clock in the afternoon, the second round of the games [will begin]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when people clap
dictionaryExamples: The crowd gave him a huge round of applause.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was unbelievable, there was a round of applause and some people couldn't help crying. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: drinks for all of the people in a group
dictionaryExamples: Would you like another round?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rob (her husband) was so happy and in such a splendid mood that he decided to pay [for] a round of beer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a group of events that is part of a series
dictionaryExamples: a round of interviews
a new round of talks between the two countries
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My life was an endless round of parties, and social events. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the roads or paths you follow to get from one place to another place
dictionaryExamples: an escape route
I'm just planning my route.
What's the best route to the station?
Crowds gathered all along the route to watch the race.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, my father and I went alone but we joined a group that was following the same route. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used as part of the name of numbered highways
dictionaryExamples: Route 9
US Route 20 runs east-west across the country from Boston, Massachusetts, to Newport, Oregon.

sense.def: a method of achieving something
dictionaryExamples: A college degree is seen by many as the best route to a good job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This means that only by presenting them with [a] great variety of opportunities can we be certain that our children will be shaped correctly. Thus, [...]  it seems to be the only legitimate and most advantag[e]ous route to follow.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the things you regularly do and how and when you do them
dictionaryExamples: Getting coffee and a bagel was part of my daily routine.
He longed to escape the routine of an office job.
We don't have a set/fixed routine - every day is different.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually we speak about our daily routine, [and] our plan[s] for the future. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: boring and regularly done
dictionaryExamples: a routine check/task
His job is very routine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, when a job becomes routine (and it usually always does), people seem to reminisce [about] their student years with a sense of disappointment. International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek

sense.def: a straight line of people or things
dictionaryExamples: a row of chairs/houses
My students sit at desks in rows for most of the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two rows of serv[a]nts stood beside the path which was in front of him with [a] red carpet on it. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a line of seats
dictionaryExamples: to sit in the back/front row
Isn't that Anita sitting in the row behind us?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is great in my class, there are so many people and they are all nice. I'm sitting in the first row next to Nicole. Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian

sense.def: one after another without a break
dictionaryExamples: He's just won the tournament for the fifth year in a row.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maradona was the captain of the team, and since he arrived, the team won three championships in a row. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to move a boat or move someone in a boat through the water using oars
dictionaryExamples: We rowed to the other side of the lake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the end, they had to row all the way back to the beach and it was very late when they got home. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: relating to a queen or king and their family
dictionaryExamples: the royal family
a royal visit
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Chris, Anne and I wanted to visit the royal palace. First Certificate in English; B2; Arabic

sense.def: to press your hand or a cloth on a surface and move it backward and forward
dictionaryExamples: She rubbed her hands together to warm them.
He rubbed himself dry with a towel.
Rub the stain with a damp cloth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Paul suddenly saw something. A kind of shadow. He rubbed his eyes but there was nothing. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to move a substance backward and forward over a surface so that it covers it and goes into it
dictionaryExamples: I rubbed some suntan oil on my arms.
If you rub linseed oil into the wood, it will protect it.

sense.def: to upset someone by talking to them about something which you know they want to forget
dictionaryExamples: I know your grades were better than mine - you don't have to rub it in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed, I wouldn't [want] to rub it in but you have reached seventy or eighty. I don't think you can fend for yourself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a strong material that bends easily, originally produced from the juice of a tropical tree, and used to make tires, boots, etc.
dictionaryExamples: shoes with rubber soles
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The [future] fashion for men I think will be suits but still made from recycled materials such as rubber and plastic. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: behaving in a way which is not polite and upsets other people
dictionaryExamples: a rude comment/remark
He complained that a member of the staff had been rude to him.
It would be rude to leave without saying goodbye.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought he [wa]s such a rude man. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: in a way that is not polite
dictionaryExamples: He pushed past us rudely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I made a[n] attempt to speak to the conductor, I was rudely told off and told to stay seated for the rest of the [trip]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a manner and attitude that is impolite
dictionaryExamples: I was shocked by her rudeness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, a person who is focus[ed] only on his goals will try to show off all his/her abilities, they will try to demonstrate their intel[l]igence and their power to the others sometimes with rudeness and intolerance. International English Language Testing System; C1; Romanian

sense.def: a soft piece of material used to cover the floor
dictionaryExamples: My dog loves lying on the rug in front of the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is [a] green rug in the middle of the floor. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: a sport played by two teams with an oval ball and H-shaped goals
dictionaryExamples: He's a keen rugby fan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to play some rugby and swim in the sea. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the broken remains that are left from an old building after it has been destroyed
dictionaryExamples: Thousands of tourists wander around these ancient ruins every year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that I'm going to travel to Luxor and see [the] ruins. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to be in a very bad state
dictionaryExamples: The city lies in ruins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When my grandparents were young, Germany lay in ruins. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: when someone loses everything such as all their money or their job
dictionaryExamples: The collapse of the bank has left many people in financial ruin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He started his first business some time ago which led to financial ruin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Lithuanian

sense.def: to spoil or destroy something completely
dictionaryExamples: They were late and the dinner was ruined.
Her injury ruined her chances of winning the race.
Huge modern hotels have ruined this once unspoiled coastline.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But she didn't keep her promise and she ruined my life. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: an official instruction about what you must or must not do
dictionaryExamples:
to break 
                          the rules
to obey/follow the rules
You can't run in the hallways, it's against the rules.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There're plenty of rules in my high school. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a principle of a system, such as a language or science
dictionaryExamples: the rules of grammar
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We did a little exam about tenses and grammar rules. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the usual way something is
dictionaryExamples: an exception to the rule
I visit my parents on Sunday, as a rule.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a rule, children who ride bikes change their bike[s] for cars [when they are older] and are pre[pa]red a little [for] how to behave on the road. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a way of judging something that is not exact but which will help you to be correct enough
dictionaryExamples: As a rule of thumb, you need one egg for every 125g flour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that I'm only one among many that have a diary a[s] their most precious possession, but, as a rule of thumb, I would think that people value objects in terms of how replace[a]ble they are. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to allow someone to do something which is not usually allowed
dictionaryExamples: We don't usually let students take books home, but I'll bend the rules on this occasion.

sense.def: when someone is in control of a country
dictionaryExamples: military rule
This area was under Polish rule until the start of World War II.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A XXth century modernist, not only should he be paid honor for his artistry but also for his never cea[s]ing battle against Franco's rule. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to be in control of somewhere, usually a country
dictionaryExamples: They were ruled for many years by the prince.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the late 60s when Greece was ruled by a military government, many young students fled abroad to escape its cruelty. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to influence someone's thoughts or actions
dictionaryExamples: His life is ruled by the demands of his job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our Earth has grown overcrowded and every inch of our life is ruled by computers. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to be in control of somewhere, usually a country
dictionaryExamples: They were ruled for many years by a dictator.
the ruling party
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cleopatra was the seventh queen of Egypt and ruled until 63 B.C. whe[n] she died. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: rule out sb/sth or rule sb/sth out

sense.def: to decide or state that something is impossible or will not happen, or that something or someone is not suitable
dictionaryExamples: It’s unlikely that he’ll run for president, but you can never rule anything out.
The police have not ruled him out as a suspect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Owning a house no longer seems to be a practical future plan and has to be ruled out, which meant that people lost their ultimate goal for working. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a flat, straight stick which is used to measure things
dictionaryExamples: Can I borrow your ruler?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  We have to bring with us a pencil and a ruler for the first lesson. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the leader of a country
dictionaryExamples: He was the ruler of the country for over 20 years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Versailles in France and the time of Louis XIV as the ruler would be my place and time I would choose to visit. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: an official legal decision, usually made by a judge
dictionaryExamples: The Supreme Court decided not to review the lower court’s ruling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you certainly will remember, the ruling of the High Court obliges you to keep the level of noise below a certain level depending on the distance of the airport. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: information that a lot of people are talking about although they do not know if it is true
dictionaryExamples: Rumors about teacher layoffs are circulating at school.
You shouldn't be spreading rumors!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He owned an inn called Jamaica but nobody would go there anymore due to some strange rumors. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to move on your feet at a faster speed than walking
dictionaryExamples: He can run very fast.
He ran away when I tried to pick him up.
We had to run to catch up with him.
I run about three miles every morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children can run ev[e]rywh[e]re. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to organize or control something
dictionaryExamples: She ran her own restaurant for five years.
The school's lunchtime café is run by the students themselves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My aunt is always working. She runs her own business. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If trains or buses are running, they are available to travel on.
dictionaryExamples: Trains are still running, despite the snow.
A bus runs  three times a day into town.
Buses are running an hour late, because of an earlier accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is an easy way to get to the college: a service bus runs every 15 minutes, [and] the journey takes only 20 minutes. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If liquid runs somewhere, it flows.
dictionaryExamples: Tears ran down her face.
Have you got a tissue? My nose is running.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Tears ran down my cold ch[ee]k as my numb fingers open[e]d the envelope. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you run a computer program, you use it on your computer.
dictionaryExamples: Did you run a virus check this morning?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At this point the computer is unable to run any program. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If a piece of equipment is running, it is switched on and working, and if you run it, you switch it on and make it work.
dictionaryExamples: She left the engine running while she went into the store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dish washer was delivered in time and installed as well, though we could not actually run the machine at that time. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: to publish something in a newspaper or magazine
dictionaryExamples: All the papers are running this story on the front page.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we run a story on "HIV Symptoms" we could have a very succes[s]ful first issue. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to try to get elected
dictionaryExamples: Kutukas ran unsuccessfully for sheriff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, I would like to suggest that aspects of his life when he was running for mayor should be included in [the] form of a speech by himself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Somali

sense.def: to move something along/over/through, etc., something else
dictionaryExamples: She ran her fingers through her hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The manly figure that had tried to stop her now kneeled before her body running his finger through her soft blond hair. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be at a particular level
dictionaryExamples: Inflation is now running at 5.8%.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to the official dat[a], unemployment is running at so high a level that it is even possible that the unemploy[ed] will rebel against the government. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: If something makes your blood run cold, it frightens you very much.
dictionaryExamples: I heard a tapping on the window which made my blood run cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This thought scared me and made my blood run cold. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to do something although something bad might happen because of it
dictionaryExamples: I think I'll run the risk of hurting her feelings, and tell her the truth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They constantly run the risk of losing their physical abilities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: If someone, especially a child, runs wild, they behave as they want to and no one controls them.
dictionaryExamples: Their nine-year-old son is left to run wild.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My parents decided to move to a small village when I was just a kid. Shortly after we settled [in], my parents decided that I was running wild and that it was time for me to receive some sort of education. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If someone's imagination runs wild, they are not able to control their thoughts.
dictionaryExamples: It was getting dark and my imagination was starting to run wild.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her imagination started to run wild and she [began] to think about the dark corridors, the secret passages and the obscure dungeons that the castle might hide. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to be very busy doing a lot of different things
dictionaryExamples: I'm exhausted, I've been running around all morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays people are running around trying to save time wherever they can, when in reality time passes far quicker when we try to save it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to secretly leave a place because you are unhappy there
dictionaryExamples: She ran away from home at the age of 13.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the age of fourteen, she ran away from home. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

blocks.phrasalVerb: run  down sb/sth or run sb/sth down

sense.def: to criticize someone or something, often unfairly
dictionaryExamples: Whatever the government do, the press will always run them down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But it's not fair to run down my country's past achievements. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: to accidentally hit something while you are driving a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: He lost control of the car and ran into a tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had tried to stop my car next to the road but I ran into a signpost. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to meet someone that you know when you did not expect to meet them
dictionaryExamples: I ran into Harry on the train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We ran into an old friend of mine and we decided to have a coffee together. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If a machine runs on a supply of power, it uses that power to work.
dictionaryExamples: My laptop is running on battery power.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Public transport will be quick and free, and run on electric power, so there won't be car pollution. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to finish, use or sell all of something, so that there is none left
dictionaryExamples: I've run out of money/ideas/patience.
"Have you got any milk?"  "Sorry, I ran out."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I have run out of time, so I have to stop writing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If a supply of something runs out, all of it has been used or it is completely finished.
dictionaryExamples: We've  run out of milk.
My patience is beginning to run out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, if you are at home and something you need has run out or broken, you can go to buy it at any time. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

blocks.phrasalVerb: run over sb/sth or run sb/sth over

sense.def: to hit someone or something with a vehicle and drive over them, injuring or killing them
dictionaryExamples: He was run over by a bus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a while, his father vanished and a car ran over John and killed him. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to repeat something in order to practice it or to make sure that it is correct
dictionaryExamples: I just need to run through my talk.

sense.def: If you run up against problems or difficulties, you begin to experience them.
dictionaryExamples: The plan for the park ran up against strong local opposition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After running up against a lot of difficulties we managed to reach our hotel. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when you move on your feet at a speed faster than walking, especially for exercise
dictionaryExamples: We go for a three-mile run every evening after work.
If you set off at a run, you'll be exhausted later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Walking is recognized [as] good exercise, or going for a run. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: in baseball or cricket, a single point
dictionaryExamples: They scored three runs in the ninth inning to win the game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I liked the competition because both the teams played well and they scored good runs. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: at a time that is far away in the future
dictionaryExamples: It seems a lot of effort but I'm sure it's the best solution in the long run.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It costs a lot of money, but in the long run, it [is] worth [it]. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to suddenly run fast in order to escape from somewhere
dictionaryExamples: When he saw the open door, he made a run for it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anna and Tom decided to make a run for it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when something happens several times without something different happening during that period
dictionaryExamples: a run of 10 games without a win
a run of good/bad luck
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Strange though it may seem, he achieved success in every possible field not owing to a run of good luck, but thanks to his outstanding qualities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: someone who runs, especially in competitions
dictionaryExamples: a long-distance runner
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The former is the fastest man in the world, th[e] latter is a very famous long-distance runner. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: the sport of moving on your feet at a speed faster than walking
dictionaryExamples: I go running three times a week.
running shoes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are reading and running. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the activity of controlling or looking after something
dictionaryExamples: The running of a large household is not easy.
He recently handed over the day-to-day running of the company to his daughter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Electricity is an essential requir[e]ment now in the day-to-day running of businesses and life in general compared to the early nineteenth century. International English Language Testing System; C2; Pashto

sense.def: If something happens for the second/third, etc., day/week, etc., running, it happens on that number of regular occasions without changing.
dictionaryExamples: He's won the Championship for the fifth year running.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fourteen days running of laziness and sleep without tight-scheduled meetings or rush-hour traffic jams lurking. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: If a building has running water, water comes into  it through pipes.
dictionaryExamples: The summer homes on the island have no running water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is hilarious to think that at the same time people in [the] north of Europe were still living a primitive and uncivilized life not even able to invent an axe, the Romans managed to install running water in their huge houses. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: a large road that aircraft use to land on or to start flying from
dictionaryExamples: The runway was covered with snow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The problem hit the headlines when a small Soviet aircraft missed the runway and touched down on a road exploding in two pieces and damaging many cars and the people sitting inside. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: relating to the country and not to cities or towns
dictionaryExamples: The area is still very rural and undeveloped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live in a rural area far from any village, town, or city. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to hurry or move quickly somewhere, or to make someone or something hurry or move quickly somewhere
dictionaryExamples: We had to rush to catch the bus.
We rushed out into the street to see what all the noise was.
The UN has rushed medical supplies to the disaster area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I rushed to Tom's house, and when I reached it, he received me with a weird smile on his face. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to do something quickly and enthusiastically
dictionaryExamples: His friends rushed to congratulate him after the ceremony.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was very happy and rushed to talk to them. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make someone do something more quickly than they want to do it
dictionaryExamples: I refuse to be rushed into making a decision.
Don't try to rush him - he needs time to think about it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has always been very busy but these days people seem to have a harder time facing the fact that not everything can be rushed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to start doing something without thinking about it enough first
dictionaryExamples: I rushed into marriage when I was much too young.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also have bad sides which are that I'm stubborn sometimes and rush into things. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when you have to hurry or move somewhere quickly
dictionaryExamples: Slow down! What's the rush?
Why is it always such a rush to get ready in the mornings?
Everyone seemed to be in a rush.
He was in a rush to get home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's because we are always stressed and always in a rush. First Certificate in English; B2; Romanian

sense.def: a lot of things happening or a lot of people trying to do something
dictionaryExamples: There was amad rush to get tickets for the concert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is that sort of a person who prefers to have more time on her hands so as to avoid the last-minute rush. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when something suddenly moves somewhere quickly
dictionaryExamples: a rush of air
She felt a sudden rush of blood to her face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To conclude, I believe that sports activities, apart from providing us with a sense of freedom and a rush of adrenaline, make us accomplished human beings. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the time when a lot of people are traveling to or from work and so roads and trains are very busy
dictionaryExamples: the morning/evening rush hour
I always try to travel outside the rush hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During rush hours, you often see cars lined up with just one person inside, each car polluting the environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: Rusty metal has rust  on its surface.
dictionaryExamples: a rusty car/nail
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was very rusty but I repainted it and now it looks like a new bike. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: If a skill you had is now rusty, it is no longer good because you have forgotten it.
dictionaryExamples: My French is a bit rusty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I am rather "rusty" [at] using the morse code as well as using the codes of communication. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: not caring if you hurt or upset other people when you try to get what you want
